STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 27, 2025
JILL SCHREUDER
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - MUSKEGON
1720 PARK ST,
MUSKEGON, MI, 49441-2403
RE: License#: CB610201023
Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on June 27, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on
central registry
• (2) A staff member must be of responsible
character and suitable and able to meet the
needs of children and families served by the
agency.
One of eight foster care files reviewed contained documentation agency worker
provided confidential information to caregiver without authorization.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 days prior to the
expiration date of the foster home license.

CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
Three of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (2) An agency shall maintain a file
documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received
by a foster child.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have all medical/dental
appointments entered in youth's MISACWIS health profile.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/31/2024 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/4/2024
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child
as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (ii) A physical examination every
14 months.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have a physical examination
completed within 14 months as required.

CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (b) Notification of the child's parents, the
responsible agency, and guardian ad
litem as applicable within 24 hours of
knowledge of the following:
• (ii) A foster child's involvement with
law enforcement authorities.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation required
parties were notified of youth's involvement with law enforcement as required.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan
completed timely as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/6/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/26/2023
7/31/2024 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/4/2024
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or
parents and the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting
the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency
shall give a copy to and review the parent-

agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan
and any other information about the child and
the child's family is confidential.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the Parent
Agency Treatment Plan (PATP) was provided to caregiver as required.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not have documentation
independent living contract was reviewed every 90 days as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Youth’s physical characteristics need to be updated.
• CPR/First Aid certification should be uploaded.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency interim inspection was completed on 7/25/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 9/4/2024. The agency was cited for 10 violations, 2 of which were
repeated this year. The number of individual incidents of non-compliance
remained the same. In 2023, 13 violations were established, 2 of which were
repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the same number
of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to establish
additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of
incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency has struggled somewhat with staff turnover since the
previous year’s audit. Hiring and training new staff has led to a time period for
learning and the potential some areas may have been missed. However, the
assessment noted the CAP developed from the previous year’s audit has been
helpful in improving areas of noncompliance.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors provide additional support and availability
as needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_________6/27/2025__________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 27, 2025
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
